content: When listening, nod and use brief verbal affirmations like "I see" to show you're engaged.
Before responding, take a breath and count to three to avoid interrupting.
Mirror the speaker's tone and energy level to build rapport.
Summarise key points after a conversation: "So, to recap, we agreed on..."
Maintain an open posture: uncross your arms and face the speaker directly.
Replace "but" with "and" to make your statements feel less confrontational.

When explaining complex ideas, use analogies related to common experiences.
To show empathy, reflect the speaker's feelings: "That sounds really frustrating."

Use "we" instead of "you" when discussing team problems to promote unity.
Eliminate filler words like "um" and "uh" by pausing instead when you need to think.

When asking questions, use "what" or "how" to encourage more detailed responses.
Practice deep breathing before important conversations to calm nerves and speak clearly.
Use hand gestures naturally to emphasise key points, but avoid excessive movement.
When writing emails, put the main action item or question in the first sentence.
In difficult conversations, acknowledge emotions: "I can see this is important to you."
Use concrete examples to illustrate abstract ideas or concepts.
When giving instructions, ask the listener to repeat them back to ensure understanding.
Maintain eye contact for about 5-7 seconds at a time to show interest without staring.
Use the "sandwich" technique: positive comment, constructive feedback, positive comment.

When apologising, be specific about what you're sorry for and how you'll improve.

1. The Flooding Smile: Hold your smile until your eyes meet the other person's, then let it flood over your face. This technique highlights the importance of a genuine smile and how to make it more impactful by delaying it until eye contact is established. It signals genuine pleasure in the encounter and is more effective than a quick smile.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 2. Sticky Eyes: Maintain eye contact for an extra beat after the other person has finished speaking. This technique emphasizes the power of strong eye contact, conveying interest and attention, and can even spark romantic feelings.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 3. Epoxy Eyes: Pretend your eyes are glued to your conversation partner's with imaginary epoxy. This technique involves maintaining intense eye contact to closely observe the other person's reactions, allowing for better understanding and analysis of their responses.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 4. Hang by Your Teeth: Imagine you are hanging by your teeth from a high wire. This focuses on posture and its impact on first impressions. By imagining this, you naturally straighten your posture, exuding confidence and importance.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 5. The Big-Baby Pivot: Turn your body fully towards the person you are meeting, as you would to a baby. This involves giving your full attention and a warm smile to the person you are introduced to, signaling that you find them special and worthy of your undivided attention.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 6. Hello Old Friend: Imagine the person you are meeting is an old friend. This helps overcome shyness and projects friendliness. This mental trick relaxes your body language and creates a more welcoming atmosphere.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 7. Limit the Fidget: Minimize fidgeting when talking to someone, especially if they are important to you. Controlling nervous movements projects credibility, as excessive fidgeting can signal nervousness or dishonesty, undermining your message.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 8. Hans's Horse Sense: Pause before speaking to gather your thoughts and appear more intelligent. This conveys thoughtfulness and prevents impulsive or foolish remarks.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 9. Watch the Scene Before You Make the Scene: Observe a group before joining to gauge the mood and dynamics. This helps avoid awkwardness and allows you to adapt your approach based on the group's atmosphere.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 10. Parroting: Ask open-ended questions to spark conversation. This encourages the other person to talk, making them feel like the center of attention and keeping the conversation flowing.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 11. Never the Naked City: Modulate your voice to sound enthusiastic and engaging. Using vocal techniques to vary pitch and tone prevents a monotonous delivery and makes you sound more interesting.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 12. Wear a Whatzit: Wear or carry something unusual to serve as a conversation starter. This unique item attracts attention and prompts people to start conversations, making it easier to connect with new people.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 13. Whoozat: Use the host's name to break into a conversation. This creates a sense of familiarity and makes it easier to approach and engage with individuals at a gathering.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 14. Eavesdrop In: Eavesdrop on a conversation and subtly join in. By politely acknowledging an overheard snippet, you provide a natural entry point and make your inclusion less intrusive.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 15. Never the Naked Introduction: Provide interesting details about your hometown beyond just the name. This enriches the typical 'Where are you from?' response, sustaining conversation and preventing dead-end answers.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 16. Come-Hither Hands: Craft a compelling one-liner that highlights your unique value proposition. Replace generic job titles with impactful descriptions that pique interest.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 17. Never the Naked Introduction: Include additional details about each person when introducing them. Providing context or conversation starters makes the interaction smoother and more engaging.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 18. Be a Word Detective: Use accidental slips of the tongue as springboards for further conversation. Paying attention to unintentional slips allows you to delve deeper into their interests or experiences.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 19. The Swiveling Spotlight: Focus your conversation on the other person's interests. Making them the center of attention makes them feel valued and creates a more positive interaction.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 20. Parroting: Repeat the last few words of the other person's statement as a question. This maintains conversation flow and encourages them to elaborate, showing that you're listening.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 21. The Leave-Behind: Engage the other person in a conversation to allow yourself to gracefully exit. Finding a suitable conversational partner ensures a smooth transition and prevents them from feeling abandoned.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 22. Accentuate the Positive: Share positive and uplifting stories about yourself rather than negative ones. Revealing positive experiences creates a more appealing impression.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 23. Be a Modern-Day Renaissance Man or Woman: Stay informed on current events and cultural trends to always have something to talk about. Reading widely allows you to engage in meaningful conversations.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 24. Employ Empathetic Language: Use the other person's name naturally throughout the conversation. Strategically using their name personalizes the interaction and makes them feel acknowledged.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 25. The Nutshell Résumé: Craft a brief and compelling summary of your professional background and goals. This allows you to effectively communicate your value proposition in networking situations.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 26. Trash the Trash-Heaps: Use descriptive synonyms to replace common and overused words. Enhancing your vocabulary elevates your language and makes you sound more articulate.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 27. Kill the Quick 'Me, Too!': Avoid instantly revealing shared interests with someone new. Delaying this revelation can create a more impactful connection and avoids appearing overeager.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 28. Comm-YOU-nication: Frame requests and suggestions in terms of the other person's benefit. Tailoring your language to emphasize their perspective addresses their 'what's in it for me?' mentality.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 29. The Exclusive Smile: Tailor your smiles to different individuals in a group, reserving your most genuine for the most important person. Offering distinct smiles to each person shows attentiveness and respect.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 30. Don't Touch a Cliché with a Ten-Foot Pole: Avoid using clichés and overused expressions in conversation. Using fresh and engaging language helps you stand out and sound original.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 31. Use Motivational Speakers' Techniques: Incorporate elements of public speaking into your everyday conversations to make them more engaging. Using storytelling and humor captivates your audience.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 32. Banter Like the Big Shots Do: Be direct and honest in your communication, even when expressing potentially controversial opinions. Expressing opinions confidently advocates authenticity and transparency.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 33. Don't Tease: Avoid teasing or making jokes at the expense of others. Being respectful and considerate maintains positive interactions.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 34. Sympathize with the Devil: Deliver bad news with empathy and understanding, acknowledging the recipient's likely emotional response. This approach demonstrates sensitivity and compassion.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 35. The Well-Timed Delay: Gracefully deflect questions you are unwilling or unable to answer. Politely deflecting unwanted questions without appearing rude helps steer the conversation elsewhere.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 36. Talking to a Celebrity: When complimenting a celebrity, focus on the personal impact their work has had on you. This genuine approach avoids typical fan behavior and feels more sincere.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 37. Never the Naked Thank You: Always express gratitude in a specific and meaningful way. Specifying what you are grateful for adds sincerity and impact to your appreciation.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 38. Be a Modern-Day Renaissance Man or Woman: Cultivate a broad knowledge base across various subjects to engage in diverse conversations. Being well-rounded facilitates connections with people from different backgrounds.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 39. Learn a Little Jobbledygook: Learn some basic terminology from the other person's profession or hobby. Familiarizing yourself with their jargon demonstrates interest and allows for informed questions.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 40. Read Their Rags: Stay updated on current issues and trends within the other person's profession. Understanding their industry's hot topics allows for more engaging and relevant conversations.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 41. It's the Way You Say It: Research and respect cultural customs when interacting with people from different countries. Understanding and respecting cultural differences prevents unintentional offense.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 42. Bluff the Buyer: Use subtle hints and shared interests to negotiate better prices or deals. Leveraging common ground enhances your negotiating position.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 43. Match Their Mood: Mirror the body language and communication style of the other person to build rapport. Subtle mirroring fosters a sense of familiarity and trust.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 44. Echoing: Use similar vocabulary and speech patterns as the other person to create a sense of kinship. Adapting your language to match theirs strengthens connection and understanding.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 45. Use Their 'Pet' Phrases: Speak the 'dialect' of shared interests or experiences to strengthen the bond. Using specific references creates exclusivity and reinforces the relationship.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 46. Speak the Other Person's Language: Avoid using jargon or technical terms the other person may not understand. Clear and concise communication ensures understanding.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 47. Employ Empathetic Language: Use short and supportive statements beyond 'uh huh' to show you are listening. Descriptive and empathetic responses demonstrate active listening.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 48. The Latest News About Them: Repeat key phrases from the other person's conversation to show attentiveness. This reinforces your engagement and helps solidify information.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 49. The Premature WE: Use 'we,' 'us,' and 'our' to create a sense of intimacy, even in early stages of a relationship. Inclusive language fosters a sense of shared experience.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 50. Match Their Mood: Observe and subtly mirror the other person's posture and gestures to build rapport. This creates a subconscious connection and makes them feel more comfortable.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 51. No-Risk Praise: Compliment someone indirectly by praising them to a mutual acquaintance. Conveying compliments through a third party feels more genuine and impactful.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 52. Pass on the Good Word: Relay positive comments you hear about someone to them. Sharing goodwill strengthens relationships and creates a positive atmosphere.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 53. Implied Magnificent Qualities: Subtly imply admiration for someone's qualities rather than stating it directly. Indirect compliments avoid overt flattery and feel more sincere.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 54. The Carrier Pigeon: Share relevant articles or information with someone to demonstrate you are thinking of them. This shows thoughtfulness and shared interests.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 55. Killer Compliment: Offer a specific and personal compliment about a unique quality you observe in someone. This makes the compliment more genuine and memorable.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 56. Little Strokes: Offer frequent, small, and genuine compliments to make someone feel good. Consistent praise creates a warm and supportive environment.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 57. The Knee-Jerk 'Wow!': Deliver compliments immediately after someone achieves a success, no matter how small. Immediate praise demonstrates genuine enthusiasm and impact.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 58. Boomeranging: Gracefully acknowledge compliments by expressing gratitude and deflecting attention. This avoids appearing boastful and keeps the focus on the interaction.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 59. The Tombstone Game: Engage in a playful exercise where you guess what positive quality someone would want on their tombstone, then reveal you believe they already possess that quality. This creates a memorable and meaningful interaction.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 60. Talking with Your Hands: Speak with enthusiasm and energy on the phone to compensate for the lack of visual cues. Varying your pitch and tone creates a more engaging experience.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 61. Name Shower: Use the other person's name frequently during phone conversations to maintain their attention. This creates a sense of personal connection and keeps them engaged.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 62. The 'I-Heard-You-Were-Great' Technique: Express enthusiasm and willingness to connect before revealing your identity to create a positive impression. This increases the likelihood of a warm reception.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 63. The Sneaky Screen: Use a vague and informal phrase like 'Is he in?' to bypass a gatekeeper. This creates a sense of familiarity and reduces the likelihood of being screened out.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 64. Salute the Secretary: Be courteous and engaging with gatekeepers to gain their goodwill and assistance. Building rapport with them increases your chances of getting through.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 65. The 'What-Color-Is-Your-Time?' Technique: Call at times when the other person is likely to be less busy or stressed. Inquiring about their availability ensures a more convenient and productive conversation.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 66. Out-of-Office, in the Office: Record a professional and concise outgoing voicemail message. A clear and efficient message ensures callers leave the necessary information.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 67. Your Ten-Second Audition: End your voicemail message with a specific call to action to encourage a response. Providing specific instructions increases the likelihood of a callback.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 68. The Ho-Hum Caper: Use the phrase 'How are you today?' with a warm and sincere tone to connect with gatekeepers. This simple gesture fosters goodwill and receptiveness.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 69. Always Be 'Under the Time Zone': Show sensitivity to time differences when communicating with people in different time zones. Considering their schedule demonstrates respect and consideration.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 70. Instant Replay: Record important business calls to review subtle cues and details you may have missed. This helps analyze the conversation more effectively.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 71. Big Shots Don't Schmooze: Avoid discussing business or personal matters during a chance encounter with someone busy. Respecting their time maintains professionalism and courtesy.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 72. Rubberneck the Room: Pause and scan the room upon entering a party to create a sense of presence. This establishes confidence and makes a memorable entrance.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 73. See No Evil, Hear No Evil, Speak No Evil: Use prolonged eye contact to signal interest in someone across a crowded room. This non-verbal cue can initiate a connection.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 74. Come-Hither Hands: Expose your palms and wrists periodically during conversation to project openness and warmth. Open palm gestures make people feel more comfortable.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 75. Tracking: Remember and reference small details about someone's life to make them feel important. This demonstrates attentiveness and strengthens the relationship.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 76. The Business Card Dossier: Write down key details about someone on their business card to remember for future interactions. This personalizes future communications.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 77. Eyeball Selling: Use targeted eye contact during presentations to identify decision-makers and gauge audience engagement. Tailoring your message ensures it resonates with key individuals.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 78. See No Bloopers, Hear No Bloopers: Overlook minor social blunders and faux pas made by others. Graciously ignoring mistakes maintains a comfortable atmosphere.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 79. Lend a Helping Tongue: Help someone recover smoothly if their joke or story is interrupted. Assisting them avoids awkward silence and shows support.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 80. Bare the Buried WIIFM (and WIIFY): Be transparent about the benefits of a proposed meeting or favor for both parties involved. Outlining mutual benefits avoids hidden agendas and fosters trust.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 81. Let 'Em Savor the Favor: Allow someone time to enjoy the feeling of granting you a favor before asking for anything in return. This strengthens the relationship without appearing transactional.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 82. Tit for (Delayed) Tat: Express genuine gratitude and offer specific ways to reciprocate a favor. Demonstrating appreciation maintains a balanced relationship.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 83. Be a Party Animal: Avoid discussing sensitive topics or bringing up work matters during social events like dinners. Focusing on enjoyment maintains a relaxed atmosphere.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 84. Be a Party Animal: Refrain from bringing up business or personal matters during chance encounters in social settings. Respecting personal time keeps interactions pleasant.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 85. Big Shots Don't Schmooze: Avoid discussing business or personal issues when encountering someone briefly in a professional setting. Keeping it light respects their time.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 86. Employ Empathetic Language: Use emotional language and personal stories to connect with people on a deeper level. Moving beyond facts to emotions creates impactful communication.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 87. The Tombstone Game: Respond to anger or frustration with understanding and empathy to diffuse the situation. Acknowledging feelings de-escalates tension.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 88. My Goof, Your Gain: Go above and beyond to compensate someone when you have made a mistake that affects them. Overcompensating shows genuine remorse and rectifies the situation.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 89. 'The Accidental Tourist' Technique: Address inappropriate behavior indirectly but firmly, allowing the other person to save face. Discreetly handling issues maintains a positive atmosphere.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 90. Buttercups for Bosses: Offer to write a complimentary letter to the supervisor of someone who provides excellent service. This gesture motivates continued excellent performance.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 91. 'I'll Get Back to You!': Engage in a conversation by expressing your opinion, even if it differs from the group's. Voicing your thoughts demonstrates independent thinking.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

content: 92. The Great Scorecard in the Sky: Consider the balance of power and favors in a relationship before making requests or decisions. Maintaining fairness and reciprocity strengthens relationships.
category: Leil Lowends 'How To Talk To Anyone' Tips

Key Message: The 48 Laws of Power offers a distillation of the universal laws that govern social and political dynamics. It provides strategic advice on navigating power dynamics in a competitive world, drawing on historical examples.

Law 1: Never outshine the master. Always make those above you feel superior. If you make your superiors feel like they are smarter, more talented, or more competent, they will favor you instead of feeling threatened.
Law 2: Never put too much trust in friends; learn how to use enemies. Be wary of friends—they will quickly betray you for their own benefit. Use former enemies as they can be more loyal.
Law 3: Conceal your intentions. Keep people off-balance by never revealing the purpose behind your actions. If they cannot understand your intentions, they cannot prepare against you.
Law 4: Always say less than necessary. The more you say, the more likely you are to say something foolish.

Law 5: So much depends on reputation—guard it with your life. Reputation is the cornerstone of power. Through reputation alone, you can intimidate and win; once it slips, however, you are vulnerable and will be attacked.
Law 6: Court attention at all costs. Everything is judged by its appearance; what is unseen counts for nothing. Never let yourself get lost in the crowd.

Law 7: Get others to do the work for you, but always take the credit. Use the wisdom, knowledge, and legwork of other people to further your own cause. Not only will such assistance save you valuable time and energy, it will give you a godlike aura of efficiency and speed.

Law 8: Make other people come to you—use bait if necessary. When you force others to act, you are the one in control. It is always better to make your opponent come to you, abandoning their own plans in the process.

Law 9: Win through your actions, never through argument. Any momentary triumph you think you have gained through argument is really a Pyrrhic victory. The resentment and ill will you stir up is stronger and lasts longer than any momentary change of opinion.
Law 10: Infection: Avoid the unhappy and unlucky. You can die from someone else’s misery—emotional states are as infectious as diseases.
Law 11: Learn to keep people dependent on you. To maintain your independence you must always be needed and wanted. The more you are relied upon, the more freedom you have.

Law 12: Use selective honesty and generosity to disarm your victim. One sincere and honest move will cover over dozens of dishonest ones. Open-hearted gestures of honesty and generosity bring down the guard of even the most suspicious people.

Law 13: When asking for help, appeal to people's self-interest, never to their mercy or gratitude. If you need to turn to an ally for help, do not bother to remind him of your past assistance and good deeds. He will find a way to ignore you.
Law 14: Pose as a friend, work as a spy. Knowing about your rival is critical. Use spies to gather valuable information that will keep you a step ahead. Better still: Play the spy yourself.

Law 15: Crush your enemy totally. All great leaders since Moses have known that a feared enemy must be crushed completely. If one ember is left alight, no matter how dimly it smolders, a fire will eventually break out.
Law 16: Use absence to increase respect and honor. Too much circulation makes the price go down: The more you are seen and heard from, the more common you appear.

Law 17: Keep others in suspended terror: Cultivate an air of unpredictability. Being predictable makes you vulnerable. Unpredictability, on the other hand, can keep your competitors or enemies uncertain, giving you an edge.
Law 18: Do not build fortresses to protect yourself—Isolation is dangerous. Isolation might seem like a good idea to protect yourself from external threats, but it can often make you an easy target.
Law 19: Know who you’re dealing with—Do not offend the wrong person. Knowing the people around you, their power, influence, and temperament is essential before engaging with them.
Law 20: Do not commit to anyone. Commitments often limit your flexibility and bind you to a certain path. Remaining neutral and not committing to anyone keeps your options open.
Law 21: Play a sucker to catch a sucker—Seem dumber than your mark. Sometimes, appearing less intelligent than you are can be an advantage.
Law 22: Use the Surrender Tactic: Transform weakness into power. Surrender is often seen as a sign of weakness, but it can become a strength when used strategically.
Law 23: Concentrate your forces. Instead of trying to be everywhere and do everything, concentrate your forces on a decisive aspect.
Law 24: Play the perfect courtier. Being a perfect courtier is about navigating social situations adeptly.
Law 25: Re-Create Yourself. You have the power to control your image and how you're perceived.
Law 26: Keep your hands clean. You must maintain an unblemished appearance by avoiding blame and associating yourself with noble causes.
Law 27: Play on people's need to believe to create a cultlike following. People have a psychological need to believe in something or someone.
Law 28: Enter action with boldness. Hesitation or half-hearted attempts often lead to failure.
Law 29: Plan all the way to the end. A powerful person doesn't just think about immediate steps but plans all the way to the end.

Law 30: Make your accomplishments seem effortless. Your actions must seem natural and executed with ease. All the toil and practice that go into them, and also all the clever tricks, must be concealed. When you act, act effortlessly, as if you could do much more. Avoid the temptation of revealing how hard you work—it only raises questions.

Law 31: Control the options: Get others to play with the cards you deal. The best deceptions are the ones that seem to give the other person a choice: Your victims feel they are in control, but are actually your puppets. Give people options that come out in your favor whichever one they choose. Force them to make choices between the lesser of two evils, both of which serve your purpose.

Law 32: Play to people’s fantasies. The truth is often avoided because it is ugly and unpleasant. Never appeal to truth and reality unless you are prepared for the anger that comes from disenchantment. Life is so harsh and distressing that people who can manufacture romance or conjure up fantasy are like oases in the desert: Everyone flocks to them. There is great power in tapping into the fantasies of the masses.

Law 33: Discover each man’s thumbscrew. Everyone has a weakness, a gap in the castle wall. That weakness is usually an insecurity, an uncontrollable emotion or need; it can also be a small secret pleasure. Once found, it is a thumbscrew you can turn to your advantage.

Law 34: Be royal in your own fashion: Act like a king to be treated like one. The way you carry yourself will often determine how you are treated: In the long run, appearing vulgar or common will make people disrespect you. A king respects himself and inspires the same sentiment in others. By acting regally and confident of your powers, you make yourself seem destined to wear a crown.

Law 35: Master the art of timing. Never seem to be in a hurry—hurrying betrays a lack of control over yourself and over time. Always seem patient, as if you know that everything will come to you eventually. Become a detective of the right moment; sniff out the spirit of the times, the trends that will carry you to power. Learn to stand back when the time is not yet ripe, and to strike fiercely when it has reached fruition.

Law 36: Disdain things you cannot have: Ignoring them is the best revenge. By acknowledging a petty problem, you give it existence and credibility. The more attention you pay an enemy, the stronger you make him; and a small mistake is often made worse and more visible when you try to fix it. It is sometimes best to leave things alone. If there is something you want but cannot have, show contempt for it. The less interest you reveal, the more superior you seem.

Law 37: Create compelling spectacles. Striking imagery and grand symbolic gestures create the aura of power—everyone responds to them. Stage spectacles for those around you, then full of arresting visuals and radiant symbols that heighten your presence. Dazzled by appearances, no one will notice what you are really doing.

Law 38: Think as you like but behave like others. If you make a show of going against the times, flaunting your unconventional ideas and unorthodox ways, people will think that you only want attention and that you look down upon them. They will find a way to punish you for making them feel inferior. It is far safer to blend in and nurture the common touch. Share your originality only with tolerant friends and those who are sure to appreciate your uniqueness.

Law 39: Stir up waters to catch fish. Anger and emotion are strategically counterproductive. You must always stay calm and objective. But if you can make your enemies angry while staying calm yourself, you gain a decided advantage. Put your enemies off-balance: Find the chink in their vanity through which you can rattle them and you hold the strings.

Law 40: Despise the free lunch. What is offered for free is dangerous—it usually involves either a trick or a hidden obligation. What has worth is worth paying for. By paying your own way you stay clear of gratitude, guilt, and deceit. It is also often wise to pay the full price—there is no cutting corners with excellence. Be lavish with your money and keep it circulating, for generosity is a sign and a magnet for power.

Law 41: Avoid stepping into a great man’s shoes. What happens first always appears better and more original than what comes after. If you succeed a great man or have a famous parent, you will have to accomplish double their achievements to outshine them. Do not get lost in their shadow or stuck in a past not of your making: Establish your own name and identity by changing course. Slay the overbearing father, disparage his legacy, and gain power by shining in your own way.

Law 42: Strike the shepherd and the sheep will scatter. Trouble can often be traced to a single strong individual—the stirrer, the arrogant underling, the poisoner of goodwill. If you allow such people room to operate, others will succumb to their influence. Do not wait for the troubles they cause to multiply; do not try to negotiate with them—they are irredeemable. Neutralize their influence by isolating or banishing them. Strike at the source of the trouble and the sheep will scatter.

Law 43: Work on the hearts and minds of others. Coercion creates a reaction that will eventually work against you. You must seduce others into wanting to move in your direction. A person you have seduced becomes your loyal pawn. And the way to seduce others is to operate on their individual psychologies and weaknesses. Soften up the resistant by working on their emotions, playing on what they hold dear and what they fear. Ignore the hearts and minds of others and they will grow to hate you.

Law 44: Disarm and infuriate with the mirror effect. The mirror reflects reality, but it is also the perfect tool for deception: When you mirror your enemies, doing exactly as they do, they cannot figure out your strategy. The Mirror Effect mocks and humiliates them, making them overreact. By holding up a mirror to their psyches, you seduce them with the illusion that you share their values; by holding up a mirror to their actions, you teach them a lesson. Few can resist the power of Mirror Effect.

Law 45: Preach the need for change, but never reform too much at once. Everyone understands the need for change in the abstract, but on the day-to-day level people are creatures of habit. Too much innovation is traumatic, and will lead to revolt. If you are new to a position of power, or an outsider trying to build a power base, make a show of respecting the old way of doing things. If change is necessary, make it feel like a gentle improvement on the past.

Law 46: Never appear too perfect. Appearing better than others is always dangerous, but most dangerous of all is to appear to have no faults or weaknesses. Envy creates silent enemies. It is smart to occasionally display defects, and admit to harmless vices, in order to deflect envy and appear more human and approachable. Only gods and the dead can seem perfect with impunity.

Law 47: Do not go past the mark you aimed for; in victory, learn when to stop. The moment of victory is often the moment of greatest peril. In the heat of victory, arrogance and overconfidence can push you past the goal you had aimed for, and by going too far, you make more enemies than you defeat. Do not allow success to go to your head. There is no substitute for strategy and careful planning. Set a goal, and when you reach it, stop.

Law 48: Assume formlessness. By taking a shape, by having a visible plan, you open yourself to attack. Instead of taking a form for your enemy to grasp, keep yourself adaptable and on the move. Accept the fact that nothing is certain and no law is fixed. The best way to protect yourself is to be as fluid and formless as water; never bet on stability or lasting order. Everything changes.
